keep.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to stay in a particular state, condition, or position, or to make someone or something do this
keep left/right (=stay to the left or right of a path or road as you move)
keep.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: You won’t be able to keep it secret forever.
Peter cycles to work to keep fit.
Don’t keep us in suspense any longer!
How can I cut your hair if you won’t keep still!
We huddled around the fire to keep warm.
I was struggling to keep awake.
some toys to keep the kids amused
The police put up barriers to keep the crowds back.
If I were you, I’d keep away from that area at night.
The little boy kept close to his mother.
You keep out of this, Mother  (=do not get involved). It’s no concern of yours.
keep.translation[0].definitions[0].note_: Keep is used as a linking verb in this meaning It links the subject of the sentence with an adjective
The fruit will keep fresh for several weeks
keep.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to continue doing something or to do the same thing many times
keep.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: I keep thinking about Joe, all alone in that place.
I keep telling you, but you won’t listen!
She pretended not to hear, and kept on walking.
keep.translation[0].definitions[1].note_: Keep is followed by an -ing form, not an infinitive You say
He kept to talk to me
keep.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to have something and not give it back to the person who had it before
keep.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: You can keep it. I don’t need it anymore.
keep.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to continue to have something and not lose it or get rid of it
keep.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: We decided to keep our old car instead of selling it.
I kept his letters for years.
In spite of everything, Robyn’s managed to keep her sense of humor.
keep.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to leave something in one particular place so that you can find it easily
keep.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: Where do you keep your teabags?
George kept a bottle of whiskey under his bed.
keep.translation[0].definitions[5].signp: make somebody stay in a place
keep.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to make someone stay in a place, especially a prison or hospital
keep.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: He was kept in prison for a week without charge.
keep.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: He should be here by now. What’s keeping him?
keep.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to do what you have promised or agreed to do
keep.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: patients who fail to keep their appointments
How do I know you’ll keep your word?
keep.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: if food keeps, it stays fresh enough to be eaten
keep.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: Eat the salmon because it won’t keep till tomorrow.
keep.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: to own and look after animals
keep.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: We keep chickens and a couple of pigs.
keep.translation[0].definitions[10].sign: stop other people from using something
keep.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: to stop other people from using something, so that it is available for someone
keep.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: Will you keep a seat for me?
keep.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: to own a small business and work in it
keep.translation[0].definitions[12].defi: to provide someone with money, food etc
keep.translation[0].definitions[12].exam: He did not earn enough to keep a wife and children.
There’s enough money there to keep you in champagne for a year!
keep.translation[0].definitions[13].exam: The Lord bless you and keep you.
His only thought was to keep the child from harm.
keep.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: keep
to leave something in one particular place so that you can find it easily
Where do you keep the scissors?
The keys are kept in my office.
store
to put things away and keep them until you need them
Villagers have begun storing wood for the winter.
to keep something so that you can use or enjoy it in the future
He had been saving the bottle of champagne for a special occasion.
We can save the rest of the pie for later.
file
to store papers or information in a particular order or a particular place
All the contracts are filed alphabetically.
collect
to get and keep objects of the same type because you think they are attractive or interesting
Kate collects old postcards.
to keep something to be used when it is needed, especially something that many different people may need to use
Medical records are now usually held on computers.
reserve
to keep part of something for use at a later time during a process such as cooking
Reserve some of the chocolate so that you can use it for decorating the cake.
hoard

to keep large amounts of food, money etc because you think you may not be able to get them in the future – used when you do not approve of people doing this because it is not necessary or not fair to other people
People have been hoarding food and fuel in case there is another attack.
Rationing of basic food products was introduced to prevent hoarding.
keep.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a large strong tower, usually in the centre of a castle
keep.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to store something that will be useful
keep.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: The Credit Reference Agency keeps files on individuals’ debt records.
You shouldkeep a supply of forms.
keep.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to regularly record written information somewhere
